comments.commentBody: So you pick a 91-year old Jew.  Still, it's better than the alternative.
Workers don't have rights.  Which was the reason for unions back in the day.
Another "pro-life" Republican.  Save every unborn child then let Mama suffer the consequences.

Have you never heard the word "antecedent"?

Every president deserves both praise and criticism, but your non-stop Obama bashing, with his name deliberately inserted into phenomena that, by the way, he had to clean up from his predecessor - who you never, ever acknowledge - is really, really tiresome.

It's amazing how the extremist wing of the GOP is able to turn every little thing into a jab at Obama. It's an obsession, the weight of which we are all bearing more and more with each passing day.

No wonder this country is in such trouble.

We should not be attempting to denigrate Assad, no matter what abuses he has committed. ISIS is a much worse evil, and Assad and Russia are at the front line of attempting to defeat it. Moreover, after Arab Spring has proved that the Middle East is ill suited to democracy after centuries of totalitarian governments, we should stop trying to force our form of government into that area,

In the meantime, we should require the EU to assume the majority of expense and manpower to defend itself, under a reasonable timeline that gives it time to do so. Since WWII, European countries have enjoyed benefits which Americans can only dream of, but only because we have payed for, and provided the manpower and military weaponry for, the lions share of its defense.

As a nation, our goal militarily should be to primarily defend our own country, not control the world. Starting with the fiasco of the Bush invasion of Iraq and leading to the fiasco aftermath of Arab Spring, this should be crystal clear.
Martin, one of my best friends is a Jew.

Would like to address just the "Russia massacres an airliner full of civilians" statement.

1. Its' ignorant to blame one side when the international team of experts have not yet announced the results of the investigation.
2. Whoever will be named responsible for the "massacre", the whole incident was a tragic mistake, by no means made intentionally. We know a number of similar cases when airplanes full of civilians were shot down - by the United States AND Ukraine including. Why vilify Russia over other countries for that matter?

Stay with the facts. Quote: "Assad crossed his "red line" of using chemical weapons" All the evidence about use of chemical weapons given to the United Nations implicated the US sponsored Good Rebels?/ISIL
not Assad used chemical weapons. The USA/Britain/France put nothing up to substantiate there false claim. Even German intelligence did not think Assad forces had used Chemical weapons. Simply more lies from the USA just like the WMD's in Iraq. Just remember it was Russia who convinced Assad to destroy all his chemical weapons and stopped the USA bombing Syria based on these lies. About the only constructive thing done by any outside party in Syria to date.

The reason why Putin or Lavrov have no one to speak with is due to the invasion of a sovereign state and justifying said invasion with keeping ethnic Russians safe. If the justification over Crimea is that it has belonged to Russia historically; thus, should remain so, then should not Kaliningrad/Konigsberg belong to Germany? The reality is Putin does not trust the democracy that put him in the position in which he is in and takes every opportunity to undermine what he perceives as the great evil of the world--the west. His short sighted, self preservationist view point is why there is state run, state funded propaganda lambasting anything that is perceived to be American in Russia.
While American foreign policy is not by any means something that one should be proud of, the idea Putin's reasoning for circumventing diplomatic channels is because "he has no one to speak to" makes you it sound like you've been drinking the kool-aid. Putin circumvents these channels to pander to the same people who desire conservative "strong" leaders that brought us to this current situation in the first place. In short, Putin benefits from the mistakes of the West because he uses said mistakes to legitimize his repressive autocracy.

It's now obvious that Putin and Lavrov have absolutely nobody to talk to, never mind negotiate with. Obama and Kerry have no plan, no ideas, nothing but the same hypocritical and sanctimonious hectoring that every American President regurgitates at these events, no matter that it's now so over the top with hypocrisy that it's simply bizarre. That's because they're absolutely powerless to formulate anything, as their role is simply that of a front-man for the MIC that dictates US policy. They are nothing more than messengers. I think Putin (amongst many) is well aware of this, and that may explain the extreme infrequency of his personal dealings with Obama. He addressed the American people directly in his NYT interview of a few years ago, and again through Charlie Rose the other evening. No matter what "side of the fence" one is on, this is cause for tremendous concern, and should be especially for the American people. They may as well have a hologram for a President.
So perhaps China will step up and engage in this mess?
we are aware, are we not, that afghanistan borders china...

It's amazing how easily all these Obama bashers forget the timeline of history. The plug was pulled on Afghanistan on March 20, 2003, when the Bush Administration diverted all energy and resources to the invasion of Iraq, based on lies over weapons of mass destruction.

Once again, this is not a problem with Obama's foreign policy.

It's a feature.

No, this is just another in the long list of Americas failed foreign policies in the Middle  East which repeatedly ignored the tribal nature of the area where any attempt whatsoever of implementing American type democracy was doomed to failure right from the outset.  How many NATO soldiers died in the process?
It really  does not matter, too much money to be made by the military industrial complex.

Used 1 Anaheim and 2 seeded serrano chiles and it was a hit with my capsaicin-addict husband. We loved the sweetness from the brown sugar, although I'm interested in swapping soy sauce for the brown sugar/salt combo to see if it generates a more savory alternate dish.

Best of all, I *finally* got a chance to use those pretty rainbow chard stems! Yay!

There are no "richer" kids at my school, but all but about 5 of my students have phones. Their parents are young enough to realize that phones today are pretty much a necessity. Instead of buying their kids a million other gadgets (laptops/tablets/ipods/etc), they simply get them a smartphone, cut the landline cost and call it done.

We do have laptops for every child--pricey brands that break constantly. The vendors who sell them make a killing and the kids get stuck with brand-new but quickly broken technology.

Kids in the private schools are using their phones in school for a variety of reasons. NOT using technology would put my students at a global disadvantage. In fact, we are required to use technology as we teach. Kids with their own phones have a better experience than the kids who have to rely on the crummy, broken-down school laptops.

America is not much liked in the Middle East because thy want to get rid of tyrants and impose their own under the guise of democracy. They don't really believe in democracy but it sounds good. Look at the mess in the Presidential race and extrapolate what their hidden agenda is. Putin should give up on Assad. You have to remember that Stalin died and was not deposed. Their system failed because of an incompetent oligarchy that could not be removed. Call it what you want but in the end the psychopath gets to the top. The people love them and then can't understand what is wrong.
I find it rather bizarre that you had even one individual agree with you.
Simple and delicious.  I sliced my garlic rather than chopping it, and added lemon zest as Carole suggested.  I stirred in a pat of butter at the end, before adding the bread crumbs.

Americans were not the only ones attempting to train security forces in Iraq. A senior Canadian RCMP officer was heading a group to help in the training. and after two years in the country, upon his arrival home and after being being interviewed, he indicated right from the outset that terrorist and other opposition groups were gradually infiltrating the trainees in which the whole process was ultimately doomed to failure.

Any wonder why ISIS has done so well and the country is fragmented now more than ever?
Add to that, out of the ashes of the Mujahadeen, whom America supplied weapons to fight the  Russians, arose,  Al Quaeda and of course, Osama Bin Laden.
Investing in Afghanistan has been a total waste of our time, labor and money....not to mention so many US lives.
Nonsense.  They're already buying mine.

So much for "let's send weapons to the 'good guys'"  Be they Afghanis, Libyans, Iraqis, or Syrians, simply allowing our military-industrial-congressional complex to reap their bloody profits by arming proxy conflicts isn't doing us any good either.

Spare us the ad hominems, Yehuda, your way hasn't worked any better than our (or your) proxy wars.  Different tactics, same results.  In Iraq we 'lead forward' which was a disaster, not only for the American military, and the credibility of our government, but for whatever was left of stability for the entire region.  As for Iran and its leadership, who cares what they do in public?  Its all for show.  We care about whether they fulfill their end of an agreement.  PR is not the same as statecraft.
